@signalboy: I don't have such experience. It is impossible - audio goes through volnorm filter calibrated at 98% of standardized SPL... always.

For n-Th time - PEOPLE have problems, mostly because they have been used to (and adjusted sound levels on playback systems) -9 to -12 dB (what is 1.5-2 TIMES) too low sound levels - improper but sadly common practice of encoders in most of the .mkv and fewer XviDs.

Even my brother in law has problems with his standalone - player+s firmware EXPECT such low levels and automatically make volume louder - and I have not to say how stupid it is...

For sake-of-god change the player, check the settings (some morons complained about the same - having their VLC set to automatically amplify volume 500%!!!) - do fucking things I have said  you before. 

You HAVE the reason, right? IF you refuse to adopt any of my advices - your stupid bitching makes sense just to - yourself.

So - I repeat: It is technically impossible. Beside that - I CHECK all files before the public relese.

Anything else is matter of medical professions - not mine. Sound in my encodings was and always would be - excellent.
